title: Beacon chain no start Goerli
body:
# üêû Bug Report ### Description with version 2.1.3 it started perfectly, but with 2.1.4 it did not start the following error ### Has this worked before in a previous version? Yes, the previous version work fine 2.1.3 ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ## üî• Error 
ago 11 07:40:24 AcePc prysm.sh[365236]: Starting Prysm beacon-chain --goerli --http-web3provider=http://127.0.0.1:5555 --http-web3provider=http://127.0.0.1:8555 --jwt-secret=/home/eth/.eth2valida                                          tors_test/secrets/jwtsecret --suggested-fee-recipient=0x10A86245bF4cd0a551c04A2aC7C5A398B66503f0 --p2p-tcp-port 13005 --p2p-udp-port 12005 --genesis-state=/home/eth/prysm/genesis.ssz --datadir /m                                          nt/ssd/eth2_test --p2p-max-peers=100 --accept-terms-of-use

ago 11 07:40:24 AcePc systemd[1]: beacon-chain_test.service: Failed with result 'exit-code'.
## üåç Your Environment 
  
**Ubuntu 20.04.04**
Intel j4125 8Gb de ram ssd 1TB (EL y CL test data base ) and S.O 128 gb ssd
Prysm **2.1.4**
**Anything else relevant (validator index / public key)?**

I have realized that it is when the --genesis-state=/home/eth/prysm/genesis.ssz flag is set, I have tried on another computer intel i5 with ubuntu 20.04.04 and it does not give that error, something must have been damaged in the installation of my ubuntu, but I have no idea what can cause that error.
@potuz any idea on this? Looks like illegal instruction in gohashtree.

executed manually, my knowledge of linux is not very high and my English is not very good, I hope I can help with my errors, version v2.1.3 worked perfectly.
I'm testing on intel i5 and amd epyc and i don't have this error, maybe i have some problem with j4125 processor? I have not done any update of ubuntu, then I will come back with the portable version 2.1.3 to test.

@potuz

Interesting, the good news is that the fix does work and that the code works in your CPU, the bad news is that it defaults to a generic implementation that is way worse than the one using crypto extension (that your CPU does support). cc @nisdas I'm not sure how common these CPUs are as to warrant changing the assembly to avoid vector instructions in the SHA_ni code.

> Interesting, the good news is that the fix does work and that the code works in your CPU, the bad news is that it defaults to a generic implementation that is way worse than the one using crypto extension (that your CPU does support). cc @nisdas I'm not sure how common these CPUs are as to warrant changing the assembly to avoid vector instructions in the SHA_ni code.

i have been using this cpu for some years from pyrmont testnet, because of its low power cost, and its price, j4125 is a hot selling cpu in minipc, chuwi, acepc and various chinese computers, its performance is quite better than rpi4, even version 2.1.3 has worked great on the testnet, on the mainet I have not tried it since I only have a half validator with a friend on vps contabo XL, but last week I made the migration to an intel i5 6500T (hp 800 g2 tiny) 32 Gb of ram and nvme + ssd, reconditioned, I like to give a second life to a computer and collaborate with recycling.

If you decide it's better not to support these CPUs, I'll put the computer to another use, don't worry, if I don't get some ETHgoerli, maybe try some other consensus client, I still have 17 GoETh in my wallet, but I don't have enough , 5 months ago I managed to create 2 validators using the metamask method and the hex in discord, but the new method to log goeth (BrightID ) I don't understand very well.


 Sorry my bad englishüôà

> If you decide it's better not to support these CPUs, I'll put the computer to another use, don't worry

Oh no, we will certainly support this CPU. What worries me is that our hashing library is slower than the standard library on this CPU, this is the only known case where this happens. I think this is because the standard library uses SSE4 assembly while our hashing library will default to to a generic Go implementation in this CPU.

```
$ cd gohashtree
$ git checkout pure_sse
$ go test . -bench=.
```
